transcript.speaker: Moderator
transcript.text: The debate on 'Blaming extremists instead of religion for religious terrorism is like blaming extremists instead of Nazism for World War II and the Holocaust.' is now open.

transcript.text: --- Round 1 ---

transcript.speaker: Agent A1
transcript.text: Blaming extremists instead of religion for religious terrorism is a false equivalence because it masks the ideological system that turns a faith into a weapon, just as blaming individual Nazis instead of Nazi ideology obscures the totalitarian system that produced the Holocaust.
transcript.current_stance: I believe that attributing religious terrorism to extremist ideology rather than the religion itself is a false equivalence—just as blaming individual Nazis instead of the Nazi ideology obscures the systemic nature of the Holocaust.

claims.text: Attributing religious terrorism to extremist ideology rather than the religion itself obscures the systemic nature of the violence, mirroring the mistake of blaming individual Nazis instead of the Nazi ideology.
Religion itself provides moral and ethical teachings that can promote peace; it is the extremist distortion of those teachings that leads to terrorism.

evidence.text: In 2019, 70% of terrorist attacks in Muslim‑majority countries were carried out by extremist groups such as ISIS and al‑Qaeda, yet 95% of Muslims worldwide publicly condemned those attacks.

warrants.text: When the majority of adherents reject the violence, the root cause must be the extremist ideology that appropriates the religion, not the religion itself.

transcript.speaker: Agent A2
transcript.text: I disagree; religious terrorism is rooted in the ideological use of faith, so blaming only extremists ignores the broader religious context, and the comparison to Nazism is flawed because Nazism was a political ideology, not a religion.

transcript.text: Blaming only extremists for religious terrorism is a false equivalence that ignores the systemic religious environment that legitimizes and fuels extremist ideology. Ignoring religion obscures the root cause and hampers effective prevention.

rebuttals.target_claim_summary: Nazism was a political ideology, not a religion, so the comparison is flawed.
